appDesc: The projections on this website provide guidance on the impact of more frequent, longer or higher coverage treatment strategies on achieving 2030 goals
howItWorks: The projections on this website provide guidance on the impact of more frequent, longer or higher coverage treatment strategies on achieving 2030 goals. The projections are model based. Please note that the models used have only been validated against a certain number of settings. A full description of the models can be found in the About section.
ourMission: Many urgent policy issues concerning the control and elimination of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) can be informed by  high-quality quantitative modelling. However, a dearth of modelling in this area prevents donors and policymakers from accessing existing expertise. We hope that our NTD Simulator can help close this knowledge gap.
whatYouCanDo: This website is for Programme Managers and Implementation Partners and allows you to investigate the potential impact of delays to MDAs due to COVID19 (or other scenarios). It contains estimates of the current prevalence in endemic implementation units, and estimates of the impact of different interruptions to the programme. This interface will allow you to adapt the mathematical modelling to your local knowledge and provide you with the analyses you need to prioritise where MDA needs to be reinstated.

backgroundAboutModelData: Background about the model and data used
modelText: is a stochastic micro-simulation of individuals with worm burden, microfilaraemia and other demographic parameters relating to age and risk of exposure. Humans are modelled individually, with their own male and female worm burden. The concentration of mf in the peripheral blood is modelled for each individual deterministically and increases according to the number of fertile female worms as well as decreasing at constant rate. The total mf density in the population contributes towards the current density of L3 larvae in the human-biting mosquito population, where the distribution of L3 amongst the human-biting mosquito population is completely homogeneous. An empirically derived relationship is used for the uptake of mf by a mosquito, where both Culex and Anopheles uptake curves are implemented depending on setting. The model dynamics are therefore divided into the individual human dynamics, including age and turnover; worm dynamics inside the host; microfilariae dynamics inside the host and larvae dynamics inside the mosquito.
InfantsTitle: Proportion of infants that will be treated.
PreschoolTitle: Proportion of preschool age children that will be treated.
SchoolAgeTitle: Proportion of school-age children that will be treated.
AdultsTitle: Proportion of adults that will be treated.
model1: The model is based on the modified SEIR framework for C. trachomatis transmission described by Pinsent and colleagues (
model2: ). Of particular significance, this model structure accounts for TF persisting after clearance of C. trachomatis, with people transitioning through four sequential states: Susceptible (S), infected but not yet diseased (I), infected and diseased (ID) or diseased but no longer infected (D). Here disease refers to clinical trachoma, specifically TF. The original ODE model has been adapted to a fully stochastic individual-based model with age and infection/disease status of individuals explicitly incorporated . Following the specifications of the original model, bacterial load and duration of infection and disease are assumed to decrease with each subsequent infection.
proportionOfPopulation: Proportion of the population covered by a bed net shared with one other person.
everyYear: Will the MDAs be every 6 months or every year?
whatProportion: What proportion of the popiulation are covered by regular indoor residual spraying.
whichMosquito: Which mosquito is the primary transmitter of lymphatic filariasis in this area.
controls: Controls how randomly coverage is applied. At 0, coverage is completely random and there is no correlation in individuals who are treated. At 1, the same individuals are treated each round. The systematic adherence parameter can scale between these two extremes.
eligiblePopulation: Proportion of the eligible population that will be treated.
simulate: What scenario do you want to simulate?
specific: Are you interested in a specific scenario?
prevalence3: Prevalence of worms in the lymph nodes
prevalence5: Prevalence of Medium and High Intensity in School Aged Children
increasingPrecision: Increasing precision means less uncertainty in the results, but longer calculation times. At the highest precision setting, this can take up to a few minutes. Do you want to proceed?
alertText1: Sorry, maximum number of Scenarios is 5.
deleteScenario: Do you want to delete this scenario?
leave: Do you want to leave this scenario?

inferredPrevalence: Inferred prevalence based on geostatistical maps interpolating through space and projected forward in time using the transmission model.
blueBars: Light blue bars show no intervention;  blue bars show intervention, the height of the blue colour shows coverage.

setup2: then click ''Predictions'' or one of the disruption buttons to simulate potential outcomes.
setup3: You can edit your setup at any time or create a new scenario.

about1: Many urgent policy issues concerning the control and elimination of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) can only be answered through high-quality quantitative modelling.
about2: However, a dearth of modelling in this area prevents donors and policymakers from accessing existing expertise. The NTD Modelling Consortium acts as a point of contact to commission modelling to address the right questions. The Consortium is also a conduit for the exchange of ideas, insights and questions between modellers and their users.
about3: Various factors motivated the creation of the NTD Modelling Consortium:
about4: — Mathematical modelling for infectious diseases and public health works best through collaborations with epidemiologists, policymakers and field experts.
about5: — Multiple modelling groups working on the same question allows us to investigate model structure uncertainty – the importance of particular underlying assumptions of each model type.
about6: — The need for structures that connect modellers and users. Designing and parameterising models raise questions about underlying biology, data availability and implementation policy structures. Conversations between these different sectors will help identify the need for studies to address key uncertainties.
about7: — NTD modelling lags behind modelling for other infectious diseases and it needs to be able to access the huge advances in the broader modelling field. With the right funding framework and the right relationship between modellers and users, new insight into NTDs will be possible.
about8: — A recruitment problem: many modellers work on NTDs for a short amount of time due to lack of funding and limited impact of publications, again as a result of the small modelling community. We need mechanisms to attract and keep infectious disease modellers in this area.
about10: The secretariat coordinates interactions between NTD MC members and external stakeholders, as well as promoting dialogue among consortium members themselves. The secretariat manages the consortium research agenda and priorities, which includes coordinating research outcomes and outputs and, the dissemination of the results to a broader audience.
about11: The NTD Modelling Consortium is led by Professor Déirdre Hollingsworth (Big Data Institute, University of Oxford) and Professor Graham Medley (London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine)
about12: The NTD MC secretariat is formed by:
abpout13: The consortium has been brought together to support the global drive to reduce the burden of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) by providing modelling estimates of the epidemiological impact of control strategies. It is a large international modelling effort with at least two modelling groups working on 7 of the 10 diseases in the London Declaration on NTDs. The current members of the NTD Modelling Consortium are:
lstmed: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine
swisstph: Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute
weLovefeedback: We welcome feedback about our website and about the work of the NTD Modelling Consortium. Please contact us for more information.
thisPage: This page should give an overview of how different teams work with data and models
LF2: Lymphatic filariasis is due to filarial parasites which are transmitted to humans through mosquitoes.
LF3: When a mosquito with infective stage larvae bites a person, the parasites are deposited on the person's skin from where they enter the body. The larvae then migrate to the lymphatic vessels where they develop into adult worms in the human lymphatic system. Infection is usually acquired in childhood, but the painful and profoundly disfiguring visible manifestations of the disease occur later in life. Whereas acute episodes of the disease cause temporary disability, lymphatic filariasis (LF) leads to permanent disability.
LF5: LF is endemic in 83 countries and there are an estimated 120 million cases, including 25 million men with hydroceles and 15 million people, primarily women, with lymphedema. The disease occurs throughout the tropical areas of Africa, Asia, the Americas and the Pacific, with around 66% of the infection clustered in South-East Asia and most of the remaining infection (~33%) centered in Africa.
LF7: LF is caused by a species of filarial round worms, or nematodes, with up to 90% of all infections caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. In some parts of Asia, LF is caused by Brugia malayi and Brugia timori.  Various mosquito species transmit these worms: Culex mosquitoes transmit W. bancrofti in urban and semi-urban areas, Anopheles mosquitoes transmit worms in rural environments, especially in Africa, and Aedes mosquitoes are responsible for transmission throughout the Pacific.
LF8: To learn more about the transmission dynamics of lymphatic filariasis, please visit the
LF11: Numerous countries have implemented LF control programmes, with significant achievements in the Americas, the Pacific and Asia. A few countries in Africa are close to their elimination goals. To learn more about LF elimination, please visit the
LF14: The underlying model is stochastic and individual-based. Its description includes an individual's worm burden, mf burden as well as aspects of the transmission cycle in mosquito populations. Various interventions are also modelled on the population. The main intervention is mass drug administration (MDA), where different regimens can be selected. Interventions also include vector control including bed-nets and insecticide treatment. A full model description can be found in the accompanying
LF16: , which can be found in the further reading section. Please note that the model has only been validated against a certain number of settings, details of which can be found in the

Cookies24: Most browsers allow you to refuse to accept cookies. For example:
Cookies25: in Internet Explorer you can refuse all cookies by clicking “Tools”, “Internet Options”, “Privacy”, and selecting “Block all cookies” using the sliding selector;
Cookies26: in Firefox you can block all cookies by clicking “Tools”, “Options”, and un-checking “Accept cookies from sites” in the “Privacy” box.
Cookies27: in Google Chrome you can adjust your cookie permissions by clicking “Options”, ”Under the hood”, Content Settings in the “Privacy” section. Click on the Cookies tab in the Content Settings.
Cookies28: in Safari you can block cookies by clicking “Preferences”, selecting the “Privacy” tab and “Block cookies”.
Cookies29: Blocking all cookies will, however, have a negative impact upon the usability of many websites. If you block cookies, you may not be able to use certain features on the website.
Cookies31: You can also delete cookies already stored on your computer:
Cookies32: in Internet Explorer, you must manually delete cookie files;
Cookies33: in Firefox, you can delete cookies by, first ensuring that cookies are to be deleted when you “clear private data” (this setting can be changed by clicking “Tools”, “Options” and “Settings” in the “Private Data” box) and then clicking “Clear private data” in the “Tools” menu.
Cookies34: in Google Chrome you can adjust your cookie permissions by clicking “Options”, “Under the hood”, Content Settings in the “Privacy” section. Click on the Cookies tab in the Content Settings.
Cookies35: in Safari you can delete cookies by clicking “Preferences”, selecting the “Privacy” tab and “Remove All Website Data”.
